INTEC Güemes 3450 Santa Fe 3000 Argentina Graphical abstract A low-loading lanthanide catalyst composed of highly disperse CeO2 nanoparticles supported on magnesium oxide hexagonal nanoplates (MgO-h) was synthesized. This catalyst showed enhanced reducibility and better catalytic performance (higher activity and full oxidation) for combustion reactions as compared to a conventional high surface area CeO2 powder. Structural characterization by transmission electron microscopy indicates that MgO-h exposes -preferably- (111) planes, allowing the anchoring of small and highly defective cerium oxide particles, with up to 18 % Ce3+. These particles activate molecular oxygen as peroxide (O2 −2) and superoxide (O2-) species. CeO2/MgO-h catalyst presented a lower apparent activation energy than the bulk CeO2 (57 versus 90 kJ/mol, respectively) for CO oxidation. As well, high oxidation activity and selectivity to CO2 are observed for toluene oxidation, that is, while bulk CeO2 produces a significant amount of CO, CeO2/MgO-h is almost completely selective to CO2 (SCO2 > 91 %). Keywords Nanocatalysts Ceria nanostructures Magnesia VOC combustion Superoxide species 1 Introduction Cerium dioxide, also known as ceria, is a widely used component or active phase in numerous redox catalytic processes [1]. CeO2 is the key material in the three-way catalysts (TWC) used in catalytic converters of vehicles with internal combustion engines, and it is included in a variety of processes such as solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs), hydrogen production (water splitting), oxygen sensors, and oxidation of pollutants [1–7]. The main chemical characteristic of ceria is its ability to reversibly accommodate a large number of oxygen vacancies under a reducing atmosphere, to give sub-stoichiometric ceria (CeOx), which can be oxidized back to CeO2 in an oxygen-containing atmosphere without structural modification of the fluorite-type structure (Ce4+/Ce3+ redox change). This feature is usually referred to as oxygen storage capacity (OSC). The high mobility of O2− ions in the crystal lattice is also important to define the catalytic performance of ceria [1,8,9]. Additionally, oxygen vacancies provide sites for molecular oxygen activation [10,11]. All those properties critically depend on particle size and morphology, which relationships are still a matter of debate [3]. Due to the technological importance of ceria, and as a rare earth material with possible supply problems [12], optimization of cerium oxide-based catalysts is under continuous scrutiny. To enhance the ceria performance, and therefore to lower its loading, many strategies have been employed such as the inclusion of secondary metal dopants [13–15] and the creation of defects in the structure [16]. Several theoretical and experimental investigations have shown that (100) and (110) planes of ceria present higher reducibility and, consequently, higher activity toward the CO oxidation and complete oxidation of volatile organic compounds [8]. Additionally, Xu et al. reported that the reducibility of ceria inversely depends on its grain size [10]. Thus, small, highly defective, CeO2 particles (<5 nm) can stabilize superoxide (O2 −) reactive species on the ceria surface. Then, numerous works have been carried out to synthesize nanostructured ceria nanoparticles, such as 2D nanoceria [16], ceria nanotubes [17], and ceria nanoparticles with controlled morphology [8,10,13]. Furthermore, it has been shown that dispersing CeO2 over suitable supports (SiO2, Al2O3, ZnO, MgO, and others) can provide a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies in the ceria nanostructures [18–21]. Herein, we describe the synthesis of highly disperse ceria nanoparticles with a high degree of surface defects supported on MgO hexagonal plates (MgO-h). A detailed characterization by HRTEM, XRD, XPS, FTIR, TPR-H2, and TPR-CO was used to investigate the morphology, composition, oxidation state and redox properties of the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst. CO and toluene oxidation were chosen to test the catalytic performances of the developed catalyst, using bulk polycrystalline CeO2 as reference material. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis MgO hexagonal nanoplates (MgO-h, see below) were prepared by a modified hydrothermal route, similar to the one reported by Ding et al. [22]. In a typical synthesis, 7.1 ml of a 0.8 M magnesium nitrate solution in deionized water (18 MOhm) was mixed with 18 ml of ammonium hydroxide solution (14 wt %) into a PTFE baker under vigorous stirring at RT. The resulting solution was kept under constant stirring for 30 min. Subsequently, the PTFE baker was introduced into an autoclave and kept at 180 °C for 24 h. The obtained Mg(OH)2 was separated by means of centrifugation at 5000 rpm, washed 3 times with deionized water, and dry in an oven at 70 °C for 24 h. Finally, the Mg(OH)2 was calcined in air at 650 °C for 24 h to give pure MgO (Figure S1). A 3 wt% CeO2/MgO-h catalyst was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation using a 0.15 M solution of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 99.99 %) in acetone. After impregnation, the sample was dried in air at 70 °C and calcined at 450 °C for 24 h. Pure CeO2, as reference material, was obtained by adding an ammonia aqueous solution (14 wt%) to a 0.15 M aqueous solution of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O [14]. The precipitated solid was filtered, dried, and calcined at 450 °C for 24 h. 2.2 Characterization A Micromeritics Accusorb 2000E instrument was used to measure the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (SBET) of the oxides. Prior to running the N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K, samples were outgassed at 473 K for 3 h under dynamic vacuum (base pressure = 1 × 10−4 Torr). The structural nature of the phases present in the calcined samples were determined by X-ray diffraction spectrometry (XRD) using a PANalytical Empyrean apparatus (Cu Kα radiation, 2°/min). The average size of CeO2 crystallites was estimated from the broadening of the (111) reflection of CeO2 by using the Scherrer equation with a dimensionless shape factor equal to 0.9. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a Multi-Technique (SPECS) equipment with a dual X-ray Mg/Al source and a hemispheric analyzer PHOIBOS 150. The spectra were obtained using pass energy of 30 eV, and the Al-Kα X-ray source was operated at 100 W. The working pressure in the analyzing chamber was less than 2 × 10−8 mbar. Before collecting the XP spectra, each sample was exposed to O2(5%)/He at 350 °C and outgassed at the same temperature (20 min). Fitting analysis was carried out using CASA XPS software. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) studies, were conducted on a JEOL 2100 Plus microscope operated at 200 kV. Images were recorded on a microscope with 0.19 nm spatial resolution at Scherzer defocus conditions. HAADF-STEM images were obtained by using an electron probe of 0.5 nm of diameter at a camera length of 8 cm. Elemental analysis studies and elemental mapping with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS) were performed using an Oxford Aztec Energy system. All samples were dispersed in anhydrous ethanol and a drop was deposited on a lacey carbon coated copper grid. In situ transmission Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was used to investigate the O2 adsorption, at 25 °C, on self-supported wafers (30 mg) of each sample pressed at 5 ton cm−2 (wafer diameter = 13 mm). The sample disks were placed into a Pyrex IR cell fitted with water-cooled NaCl windows. The IR cell was attached to a conventional high vacuum system (base pressure = 1 × 10-4 Torr), equipped with a manifold for gas flow operation. Before the adsorption of O2, the sample was cleaned as follows: i) heating from RT to 450 °C (10 °C min-1) in a flow of pure O2 (50 cm3 min-1), ii) evacuation at 450 °C during 15 min; iii) reduction under flowing H2 (50 cm3 min-1) at 450 °C for 60 min, iv) cooling to 125 °C still under H2 flow, v) evacuation at 125 °C during 15 min, vi) cooling to 25 °C under dynamic vacuum, and vii) adsorption of O2 10 Torr at 25 °C. The redox properties of the support and catalyst were studied by temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) with hydrogen and carbon monoxide using mass spectrometry. The experiments were performed on 200 mg of the sample placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. The evolved gases were analyzed with a Prisma QMG220 (Pfeiffer) quadrupole mass spectrometer. Before running the TPR experiments, the samples were submitted to a cleaning procedure as follows: heating the oxides in a flow of 5%O2/He (50 cm3 min−1) at 450 °C (1 h), followed by cooling to 100 °C under the oxidizing mixture, and further to 25 °C in a flow of He (20 cm3 min−1). Both diluted hydrogen, 5%H2/Ar, and carbon monoxide, 5%CO/He, were used as reducing agents for the TPR experiments (hereafter, TPR-H2 and TPR-CO, respectively). The flow rate was 50 cm3 min−1, and the heating rate from 25 to 700 °C was 10 °C min−1. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic performance for CO or toluene oxidation was measured in a fixed bed glass tubular microreactor (i.d. = 5.3 mm). Light-off curves were evaluated from 100 to 500 °C (5 °C min−1). The composition of the reaction mixture was 1% CO or 3200 ppm toluene and 20 % O2 for CO or toluene oxidation, respectively, balanced with He. The desired concentration of toluene in He was obtained from a gas saturator filled with pure toluene immerse into a thermostatic bath. All lines in contact with toluene were heated to prevent condensation. Total flow and catalyst weight were tuned to have the same weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) based on ceria loading and carbon containing reactant [23]: 5.0 g C O g C e O 2 - 1 h - 1 and 7.9 g C 7 H 8 g C e O 2 - 1 h - 1 for carbon monoxide and toluene oxidation, respectively. The activity measurements with MgO-h were carried out maintaining the WHSV used with CeO2/MgO-h (0.15 g C O g C a t - 1 h - 1 and 0.24 g C 7 H 8 g C a t - 1 h - 1 ). The reactor was loaded with the appropriate mass of each catalyst diluted (1:6) with milled quartz (200 mesh). The absence of internal/external mass and heat transfer limitation was verified and the reactor was always operated within the kinetic regime (see Supplementary Information). Before the study of the catalytic performance, each sample was pretreated at 400 °C under flow of 5% O2/He (60 cm3 min−1) for 1 h. The outlet gas stream was analyzed continuously with a mass spectrometer Prisma QMG220 (Pfeiffer). The following mass/charge signals were recorded: 4 (He), 18 (H2O), 28 (CO), 29 (H2CO), 32 (O2), 40 (Ar), 44 (CO2), 77 (benzaldehyde, C7H6O) and 91 (toluene, C7H7 +). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization Table 1 summarizes the chemical composition and textural properties of the samples. MgO support presents a surface area of 17 m2/g, which is almost preserved after deposition of ceria (nominal loading: 3 wt%). Fig. 1 presents the powder XRD patterns. Pure ceria shows the characteristic peaks of a cubic, fluorite-type, structure (ICDD PDF-00-034-0394), with a mean crystal size domain of 9 nm, as determined from the Scherrer equation. The MgO nanoplates support presents peaks due to the cubic, crystal rock-type, structure (ICDD PDF-01-075-0447), with a crystal size domain of 17 nm. Small peaks of CeO2 are observed in the supported catalyst, which are significantly broader than those for bulk ceria, indicating a smaller mean crystal size, estimated at 4.7 nm. The nanostructural and morphological analysis was performed by electron microscopy. MgO nanoparticles present an overall hexagonal-plate morphology (MgO-h), with an edge length of around 500 nm and ca. 100 nm thick (Fig. 2 ). A closer inspection shows that plaques are composed of “fused” or aggregated MgO thin nanocrystals (Figure S2), which organize in hexagonal-flat morphology. Digital diffraction pattern (DDP) displays spots pattern of (220) planes, slightly tilted in the direction of (111) surface. The observed lattice fringes with 0.15 nm spacing are in perfect agreement with the d-spacing in bulk MgO (0.149 nm). Fig. 3 and Figures S3 to S5 show some representative HRTEM and HAADF-STEM images of the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst. Due to the high atomic number difference between Mg (Z = 12) and Ce (Z = 58) a very good contrast is observed in the images, which reveals a homogeneous distribution of small CeO2 nanoparticles on MgO-h support. EDXS analysis, also corroborates the high dispersion of ceria, with an average content of 3.5 wt.% (very close to the nominal loading). HRTEM images show the presence of small particles of CeO2, with a mean size of 5.4 nm (Figure S7). Part of the CeO2 nanoparticles has a characteristic morphologic shape, which apparently exposes the (111) plane (d-spacing of 0.31 nm), retaining the typical cubic, fluorite-like, structure of ceria, (Fig. 3). The relative orientation between CeO2 nanoparticles and MgO support was analyzed from the digital diffraction patterns (DDPs) of the HRTEM images (inset Fig. 3). Epitaxial growth of CeO2 particles through the (111) plane, slightly rotated, on top of (111) MgO surface is observed. The (111) CeO2 plane presents an oxygen-to-oxygen distance of 0.383 nm, but the (111) MgO has a distance of 0.298 nm, which could explain the partial mismatch between both faces. Additionally, the smallest CeO2 particles present a low crystalline structure, most likely similar to irregular aggregates of CeO2, with a high degree of defects as will be addressed further (Figure S3). Small (highly defective) CeO2 nanoparticles are stabilized on top of the (111) MgO surface. Similar observations were reported by Tinoco et al. [21] on a ceria supported on a commercial MgO powder and by Luo et al. [24] on a CeO2/TiO2 system. 3.2 Chemical characterization In addition to the structural studies presented and discussed in the previous section, we have also investigated the effects of the high dispersion of ceria on their redox properties. 3.2.1 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS analysis was performed to obtain information about the oxidation state of the supported ceria catalyst compared with the pure polycrystalline ceria. Fig. 4 compares the XP spectra of both samples after degassing at 350 °C for 20 min. Ce3d core level signals were used to calculate the Ce3+ relative concentration according to the procedure detailed in the Supplementary Information. Quantification of the Ce3d spectra indicates that the amount of Ce3+ in the bulk CeO2 is below the limit of detection [25,26]. In the case of the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst as much as 18 % of Ce3+ is observed. Clearly, the supported CeO2 nanostructures exhibit a much higher vacancy formation capacity than bulk ceria. Similar results were reported on CeO2 nanoshapes [10] and ceria thin films (< 5 nm) [25,26]. Xu et al. [10] systematically investigated the size effect of ceria nanoparticles on its redox performance. They reported that below 5 nm the total amount of reducible Ce4+ dramatically increases due to a higher amount of low coordination Ce sites. Our results on CeO2/MgO-h are in agreement with that observation. 3.2.2 Temperature programmed reduction studies under H2 and CO In order to explore the reducibility, temperature programmed reduction with H2 and CO followed by mass spectrometry were performed (TPR-H2 and TPR-CO, respectively). Both probe molecules provide different insights into the reducibility of metal oxide due to the different mechanisms involved. On one hand, the hydrogen molecule must be first adsorbed and dissociated on surface sites to react with lattice oxygen to form water and to reduce Ce4+ to Ce3+. On the order hand, CO is adsorbed without dissociation and reacts with lattice oxygen to produce carbon dioxide, while reducing Ce4+ to Ce3+ [27]. MgO-h support is included for comparison, showing that its contribution to the TPR traces is almost negligible, as expected from the literature [21,28,29]. The TPR-H2 diagrams, normalized by weight of ceria, are depicted in Fig. 5 . The trace for pure ceria shows that water evolution starts at ca. 350 °C with a peak at 428 °C, overlapped with a high temperature band centered at 534 °C. It is generally acknowledged that the signal emerging at lower temperatures is assigned to a surface reduction process, whereas the peak at higher temperature is due to the bulk reduction of ceria [30–33]. Meanwhile, the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst shows a significant enhancement of its reducibility as compared with bulk ceria (Fig. 5). TPR-H2 curve presents a low-temperature peak at 187 °C and a high-temperature peak at 530 °C, and a water production 3-fold higher compared to pure CeO2 per mass of ceria. A similar TPR-H2 profile –including a low-temperature peak T < 200 °C, was also reported by Wu et al. for CeO2 nanorods and nanocubes [34]. The results of the TPR-CO study, normalized by weight of ceria, are summarized in Fig. 6 . For CeO2, two reduction peaks at 268 and 338 °C are observed, as expected for a high surface area cerium oxide, that is, the reduction by CO is facilitated as compared to H2 as a reducing agent [30]. In the case of the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst, a small peak is registered at ca. 170 °C, followed by a broad reduction band centered at 315 °C and a further weak peak at 568 °C. In general terms, during the reduction of ceria, an oxygen vacancy is formed with electrons transferred to two adjacent cerium atoms, generating the reduction from Ce4+ to Ce3+: CeL +4 + O−2 L → VO + 2 CeL +3 + ½ O2 where L stand for lattice site and VO stands for an oxygen vacancy [35]. The reducibility of ceria, that is, vacancy formation, has been related to surface crystal geometry and particle size. The most stable surfaces of ceria are (111), (110) and (100) planes. Among them, the (111) surface is the most compact, with the highest coordination, and therefore the less reducible; while the (110) and (100) planes are more reducible. DFT calculation shown that vacancy defect formation follows the order: 2.60 eV (111) > 2.27 eV (110) > 1.99 eV (100) [36]. In this regard, nanocubes and nanorods, which preferentially expose (100) and (100)/(110) planes, respectively, have shown higher reducibility than octahedral ceria nanoparticles with a prevalence of (111) surfaces [37]. Likewise, it has been suggested that the reducibility of CeO2 nanoparticles strongly depends on the crystal size [10,38]. A large increase in oxygen vacancy concentration in CeO2 nanoparticles with sizes lower than 5 nm was reported by Xu et al. [5] and Zhou and Huebner [38]. Then, the increase of the surface to volume ratio, as decreasing the particle size, exposing low coordination atoms, could lead to a higher redox property in ceria nanoparticles [10]. Therefore, the improved reducibility of CeO2/MgO-h catalyst as compared with bulk ceria and disclosed by our XPS and TPR tests, is attributed to the highly defective CeO2 nanoparticles supported on MgO-h plates. 3.2.3 Adsorption of O2 on pre-reduced catalysts The adsorption of molecular oxygen on the different materials was studied by in situ FTIR in order to identify adsorbed O2 species. Figure S8 depicts the IR spectra obtained under flowing pure H2 at 450 °C. The spectra show the characteristic band at ca. 2120 cm−1, which is assigned to a forbidden electronic transition of the Ce3+ cations (2F5/2 → 2F7/2) [39]. The intensity of this signal can be correlated with the reduction degree reached by ceria. It is noticeable that the signal is slightly shifted in the supported ceria as compared with the pure CeO2. Again, a higher reduction –as revealed by the band at 2120 cm−1, is observed: the integrated absorbance normalized by mass of CeO2 was approximately 2-fold higher for the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst than for bulk ceria (233 vs. 109 integrated absorbance values, respectively). After reduction, the IR cell was cooled to room temperature and 10 Torr of pure O2 were introduced. In the case of pure CeO2, a negative band at 2117 cm−1 due to the reoxidation of Ce3+ is observed, along with the rise of a very weak peak at 1128 cm−1, assigned to the OO stretching of superoxide (O2-) species on Ce+3/Vo sites [32,33] (Fig. 7 ). Furthermore, positive bands are registered at 879, 843, and 832 cm−1, which can be ascribed to peroxide (O2 2-) species adsorbed on Ce surface sites [32,33,40,41]. Nevertheless, the proper assignments of these IR last bands needs to be study further. IR spectrum for the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst after oxygen adsorption shows, as well, a negative band at 2121 cm−1 due to the reoxidation of Ce3+, along with the rise of a very strong peak at 1125 cm−1 of superoxide species, and several peaks in the region of 950−800 cm−1 as assigned to peroxide species [32,33,40,41]. As it was mentioned before, the accurate assignation of peroxide species is not possible at this time. The integrated area of the superoxide band at 1125 cm−1, normalized by ceria surface, is 0.89 Abs/m2 CeO2 for the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst, but only 0.034 Abs/m2 CeO2 for the bulk ceria. That is, cerium oxide nanoparticles adsorb 30-fold more superoxide species than the bulk material. Overall, the supported ceria nanoparticles seem to stabilize superoxide species more efficiently than bulk CeO2. 3.3 Catalytic tests 3.3.1 Carbon monoxide and toluene oxidation Fig. 8 shows the light-off curves of the CO oxidation during the heating ramp between RT and 500 °C over the CeO2 and CeO2/MgO-h catalysts and the bare support for comparison. To compare the catalytic activity of bulk and supported ceria, the same CO concentration (1 %) and identical weight hourly space velocity ratio (5.0 g C O g C e O 2 - 1 h - 1 ) were employed at 1 atm of total pressure. Under these conditions, the activity onset for the CO oxidation starts at approximately 260 °C for the pure ceria material, with a light-off temperature (T50: 50 % of CO conversion) at T50 = 408 °C. At its turn, the conversion curve for CeO2/MgO-h is down-shifted in temperature, showing an onset at 230 °C, with a T50 = 340 °C. Thus, almost a 70 °C decrease in the reaction temperature was observed comparing vis-à-vis the dispersed ceria nanoparticles on MgO-h with bulk ceria. Note that the CO conversion on the magnesia support is always lower than 20 %, even above 500 °C. The turnover frequency (TOF) estimated at 300 °C was 4.2 × 10−3 s-1 and 2.3 × 10−3 s-1 for CeO2/MgO-h and CeO2, respectively (see Supplementary Information). Apparent activation energies (Ea) were calculated for both catalysts under differential conversion (XCO < 10 %) (Figure S9). While the Ea was equal to 90 kJ/mol for pure CeO2, this value decreased to 57 kJ/mol for dispersed CeO2 on MgO-h. Our Ea for bulk ceria is congruent with those reported for pure –polycrystalline- ceria (92.7 kJ/mol) by Schmieg and Belton [42] and for thin sheets of CeO2 (89.1 kJ/mol) by Sun et al. [16]. Nevertheless, the Ea decreased to 61.7 kJ/mol for the CeO2 sheets that contained surface-confined pits (defects) [16]. Likewise, Lykaki et al. [43] obtained an Ea value equal to 43.7 kJ/mol for rod-like ceria, evidencing that a change in morphology has a significant impact on the activation energy of the CO oxidation reaction. Zhang et al. [44] and Wang et al. [45] also reported similar results on nanowires, nanorods, nanocubes, and nanofibers with respect to bulk ceria. Wu et al. [34] investigated the structure dependence of CO oxidation over CeO2 nanocrystals with defined surface planes: rods (110)/(100), cubes (100), and octahedra (111). They found that the CO oxidation activity followed the order: rods > cubes > octahedral. Under a classic Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism, these authors suggested that the catalytic activity towards CO oxidation is correlated with the reactivity of the lattice oxygen on different ceria surfaces, i.e. they proposed that the lower the surface oxygen vacancy formation energy and the higher oxygen mobility, the higher the activity for that reaction [46,47]. During TPR-CO experiments, CO2 is produced due to the reaction of CO with active lattice oxygen species (O2−) [30,34]: 2Ce4+ + O2− + CO(g) → 2Ce3+ + Vo + CO2 (g) In this regard, our TPR-CO results showed that CO oxidation by lattice oxygen is enhanced on CeO2/MgO-h catalyst as compared to pure CeO2 (Fig. 7). Thus, lower energy for vacancy formation is in agreement with the lower activation energy for the CO oxidation reaction found on the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst. Additionally, recent operando Raman investigations put into relevance the role of adsorbed oxygen species, peroxide and superoxide, on the catalytic activity of ceria-based catalysts for combustion reactions [48–50]. Sun et al. [16] presented experimental and theoretical results on well-defined ceria systems, e.g. CeO2 sheets with a controlled concentration of oxygen vacancies, where the elementary step of O2 activation has been proposed as the rate-limiting step for the CO oxidation on CeO2. Based on the above results, it could be suggested that the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst, with a large amount of ceria defective nanoparticles, presents highly active sites for CO oxidation due to the enhanced capacity to activate molecular oxygen compared with polycrystalline CeO2, lowering the overall activation energy of this reaction. In other words, the improvement of superoxide species formation after O2 adsorption on our pre-reduced supported-ceria nanoparticles, as discussed in the previous section, could account for the higher activity for CO oxidation on the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst as compared with bulk polycrystalline CeO2. Thus, both O2 adsorption and TPR-CO results are in line with the higher activity for CO oxidation on the supported catalyst. Finally, the catalytic oxidation of toluene was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor between 100 and 500 °C. This is a far more complex –and demanding- reaction, which requires multiple elementary reaction steps for total oxidation of that aromatic compound. Fig. 9 shows the toluene conversion vs reaction temperature for pure CeO2 and CeO2/MgO-h catalysts under identical reaction conditions. The light-off curve for MgO-h is shown in Figure S10. Pure ceria presents a significant conversion of toluene, showing a T50 at ca. 280 °C, as previously reported in the literature [9,25,26]. However, according to the toluene total oxidation (C7H8 + 9 O2 → 7 CO2 + 4 H2O), the combustion is not complete. Carbon monoxide, as a partial oxidation product, is observed in all temperature range. MgO-h support shows a poor catalytic performance, with an onset temperature around 450 °C, reaching only 30 % of conversion at 550 °C and mainly producing CO, in agreement with previous reports [29]. Conversely, and relevant for industrial applications, CeO2/MgO-h presents a toluene conversion profile with a T50 = 343 °C and an almost complete selectivity to CO2, always higher than 91 %. It is interesting to note that, the onset temperature for toluene oxidation is around 150 °C for the CeO2/MgO-h (see Fig. 9). TEM images of post-reaction CeO2/MgO-h sample (see Figure S11 and S12) show that small ceria nanoparticles remains stable after the reaction cycle. Several recent investigations have reported on the catalytic oxidation of toluene, as a representative VOC molecule, on nanostructured cerium oxide. Lopez et al. [9] investigated the toluene oxidation on CeO2 nanoshapes and reported that nanorods showed an order of magnitude higher activity than ceria nanocubes. They suggested a correlation between the catalytic activity of nanostructured ceria with the concentration of surface oxygen defects. Peng et al. [51] also studied the toluene oxidation on CeO2 nanorods and nanocubes (and platinum supported on them). They also reported an increase in the oxidation rate with the number of oxygen vacancies, being rods more active than cubes. Liao et al. [52] obtained similar conclusions for CeO2 nanorods and nanoparticles. Recently, Wang et al. [50] found an increased performance for toluene oxidation on CeO2 nanosheets prepared using a MOF precursor, which presents well-crystallized CeO2 (110) planes, compared to CeO2 nanorods. Similarly, the authors related the catalytic performance to a higher content of defects and oxygen vacancies on CeO2 sheets. Their operando Raman studies suggest that superoxide and peroxide species could directly participate in the oxidation of toluene on CeO2. Thus, the higher concentration of superoxide/peroxide species in the CeO2/MgO-h catalyst could be responsible for the higher selectivity for toluene oxidation. Nevertheless, further spectroscopic investigations are needed to unveil the role of the oxygen species during the reaction. In summary, the improved redox property, related to defect sites (oxygen vacancies/Ce3+ sites), able to stabilize activated oxygen species –peroxide and superoxide-, seems to be a key factor to improve the performance oxidation reactions on nanostructured cerium oxide catalysts, with optimized loading. 4 Conclusions A successful strategy for producing highly disperse CeO2 nanoparticles with enhanced redox properties is presented. Hexagonal-shape MgO nanoplates (MgO-h), exposing (111) surface, were synthesized via hydrothermal synthesis and subsequent calcination. Supported 3.0 wt% cerium oxide over MgO-h was prepared by the impregnation method. The synthesized CeO2/MgO-h catalyst presents small CeO2 nanoparticles (dmean =5.4 nm) homogeneously distributed over the support, with a partial match between the (111) planes of CeO2 and MgO. The small -defective- CeO2 nanoparticles contain as much as 18 % of Ce3+ (oxygen vacancies), which improves reducibility and stabilizes a higher concentration of superoxide (O2 −), and peroxide (O2 -2), surface species than bulk CeO2. Supported CeO2 nanoparticles displayed increased oxidizing potential compared to the bulk phase. The lower activation energy for CO oxidation (57 kJ/mol) and high selectivity to CO2 during toluene oxidization is related to the enhanced redox capacity and higher presence of oxygen vacancies (and peroxide/superoxide species) of the supported nanoparticles. It is expected that this approach will help to the rational design of optimized, low lanthanide loading, ceria-based catalysts. Author statement Esteban L. coredata.dc:description: A low-loading lanthanide catalyst composed of highly disperse CeO2 nanoparticles supported on magnesium oxide hexagonal nanoplates (MgO-h) was synthesized. This catalyst showed enhanced reducibility and better catalytic performance (higher activity and full oxidation) for combustion reactions as compared to a conventional high surface area CeO2 powder. Structural characterization by transmission electron microscopy indicates that MgO-h exposes -preferably- (111) planes, allowing the anchoring of small and highly defective cerium oxide particles, with up to 18 % Ce3+. These particles activate molecular oxygen as peroxide (O2 −2) and superoxide (O2-) species. CeO2/MgO-h catalyst presented a lower apparent activation energy than the bulk CeO2 (57 versus 90 kJ/mol, respectively) for CO oxidation. As well, high oxidation activity and selectivity to CO2 are observed for toluene oxidation, that is, while bulk CeO2 produces a significant amount of CO, CeO2/MgO-h is almost completely selective to CO2 (SCO2 > 91 %).
coredata.dc:title: Highly disperse CeO2 nanoparticles on MgO hexagonal plates as oxidation catalyst
